nodes.text: Increasing sleep among the urban poor will improve economic outcomes, cognition, productivity, decision making, and well-being
Context: Urban poor in Chennai face environmental and psychological barriers to good sleep (heat, noise, crowding, distress), motivating study of sleep deprivation and its returns

Baseline evidence (actigraphy): low-income adults in Chennai sleep 5.5 hours nightly on average, spend ~8 hours in bed, have ~31 awakenings per night, and average sleep efficiency ~70%, comparable to clinical insomnia/apnea samples

Method: Randomized controlled trial (N=452) with 28-day data-entry employment, continuous actigraphy, cross-randomized night-sleep treatments (devices+encouragement or devices+incentives) and an afternoon nap treatment, many outcome measures (productivity, labor supply, cognition, well-being, preferences)

Result (treatment impact on sleep): Night-sleep treatments increased nighttime sleep by 27 minutes/night on average (incentives > encouragement), driven entirely by increased time in bed (~38 minutes) rather than improved sleep efficiency

Result (nap treatment on sleep): Nap treatment increased daytime sleep by about 14 minutes/day on average (with slightly reduced nighttime sleep), and naps in the office had higher sleep quality (higher efficiency) than night sleep at home

Result (economic and cognitive outcomes): Increased nighttime sleep had no detectable positive effects on the overall summary index, cognition, productivity, decision making, well-being, or preferences; it reduced labor supply (~9 minutes/day) and led to small non-significant decreases in earnings/output

Result (nap outcomes): Afternoon workplace naps improved an overall index by 0.12 standard deviations, with significant increases in productivity, psychological well-being, lab cognition measures and attention to incentives, but decreased work time and thereby could reduce earnings relative to working during that time

Claim: Naps and increased night sleep are not equivalent substitutes per minute; per-minute effects of naps on summary outcomes and some families (cognition, preferences, psychological well-being) are significantly more positive than per-minute nighttime sleep (IV analysis)

Evidence: Expert priors from surveyed sleep and economics experts predicted sizable economic gains (median predicted 7% increase in output from +30 min night sleep), but actual RCT results reject those predictions strongly (e.g., 7% output increase rejected, p<.001)

Conclusion: In this context, marginal increases in nighttime sleep via increased time in bed do not produce expected short-run economic or cognitive benefits; short workplace naps, however, yield measurable benefits on several outcomes

Policy implication / claim: Interventions to increase sleep must consider sleep quality and opportunity costs; providing comfortable workplace nap opportunities may be a cost-effective way to improve productivity, cognition, and well-being for sleep-deprived workers

Assumption / alternative explanations: Possible reasons for null night-sleep effects include (a) marginal increases differ from extreme lab deprivation experiments, and (b) low sleep quality (low efficiency, frequent awakenings) limits returns to additional sleep

Limitation: Short treatment horizon (~3 weeks), single-city sample, bundled night interventions, and potential external validity constraints; cannot fully separate timing versus sleep-quality channels for nap vs night-sleep differences

Conclusion / future research claim: More field studies across contexts and interventions that improve sleep efficiency are needed to assess long-run health and economic returns to sleep and to generalize lab findings to real-world settings
